body: Seems fair @acsbendi, thanks for reporting it !
Hi, everyone. Would like to work on this. @scordio @joel-costigliola please, assign to me if possible. Thank you in advance.

Hi, again. Sorry for being late, only now I found some time to look at the issue. Here is the approach I implemented, but did not write tests and documentation. I wanted to get your opinions as well since I did not like my this approach a lot but could not find any better solution without making lots of changes. Please, let me know if this is okay to continue with.

1. As suggested, I add a static boolean variable in Assertions, by which printing of the instance can be enabled (disabled by default).
2. in https://github.com/assertj/assertj/blob/4c7be374cdcc939ee22c3eb3c3672fb15de6feee/assertj-core/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractAssert.java#L983, I check that boolean variable. 

If true, then I create a new `AssertionError`, setting 
its message to - the display of the actual instance (e.g. For FullArticle(article=Article(status=FAILED, manuallyDiscarded=true, discardReason=...))) + the original message, 
its stack trace to the original stack trace.

Else, the flow goes as it is now.

I think we could even start with a simpler approach by always including the root object, then if users complain, we can add an option not to (having more information in the error is a good thing unless proven otherwise).
Okay, then. I will follow the same approach, except, always including the root object. Thank you

Hi, there. I found out that in case of some failures, `AssertJMultipleFailuresError` is thrown. So, my approach of creating a new `AssertionError` does not work. I thought of creating the instance using reflection and throwing `AssertionError` in case an exception occurs during reflection. But this does not seem okay to me. I am thinking of passing the actual instance to the methods until the parts that the exception message is formed. What do you think?
@alihmzyv could raise a PR as a draft, it will be easier to follow what you are doing, thanks !

Hi, @joel-costigliola, I linked a pr. Please, check it out. 
To make the tests pass, I hade to refactor the test written for the case  that `MultipleAssertionsError` is thrown. The tests for the case that `AssertJMultipleFailuresError` is thrown still passes as they use not equality, but "contains" checks, so I left them as they are. If you see a need for update, I can refactor those tests as well. Thanks.

issue.title: include root object in failure messages. closes #3948.

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM
